WRITING.TITLE: Books about life in the USSR under Stalin?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm looking for some books about pre-WWII Russia, specifically about gulags. Are there any books written by survivors or give an account of life in a gulag? Honestly, even a fact-based fictional story would be good too. Coming from a country where we can be open about our ideas and speak freely, I have always been intrigued by stories of oppression. Also, the secretive nature of gulags has me very curious

The founders wanted a President who was politically involved and aware of current issues. Nowadays we can follow politics and issues from anywhere in the world, but back then they had no idea what was going on around the world until weeks after it happened. So by making sure that the President was a resident, they ensured that he/she knew what was going on.
Just one possible theory

He appealed to the common American and seemed down to Earth to most Americans. Also, the 80's were a period of economic prosperity which is commonly associated with him, so people were happy because they had money. He also was very strong with regards to the Cold War and the Iranian Hostage Crisis, which made most Americans respect him and trust him.
Years later though, we see that some of his policies turned out to be ineffective and have lasting negative impacts on America (ex. Reaganomics, War on Drugs), which is why he isn't as well-accepted nowadays.

The people at the time weren't necessarily opposed to a central figure, they were opposed to an oppressive central figure with too much power. Everyone in the U.S. loved Washington at the time, so this helped to assuage their fears of an overly-powerful central figure. The system that the Constitution originally set up included more state power with the 10th amendment being the driving factor. So in the time period, states did have more rights.
The federalists also had the backing of large states like Virginia through James Madison. He along with Alexander Hamilton published the Federalist Papers, which convinced smaller states as well as the general population that a strong centralized government was ideal for the new country.
Pogba left because of the money. United is able to pay players wages that we simply can't. That's why he went despite them not being in the CL.

WRITING.TITLE: Can anyone recommend books on ancient civilizations?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm looking for a book that discusses the dynamics and characteristics of several different ancient civilizations. I've gotten very bored in class recently, and have taken to browsing Wikipedia in my free time, looking at this kind of stuff. In addition, high school social studies curriculums don't really talk about this kind of stuff, which has only furthered my curiosity.
I know the basics of these societies, but I'd like to learn more about the political, social, and societal dynamics of these civilizations. I'm assuming there are books that go into detail about ancient civilizations but I'm not sure where to start looking, and I thought it would be worthwhile to try r/history for some suggestions.

WRITING.TITLE: Looking for a book about ancient civilizations
WRITING.TEXT: Primarily looking for non-fiction that delves deep into the dynamics, organizations, and characteristics of specific ancient civilizations.
